reviewText:
There isn’t much of a game here.  You watch videos based on your selection and the only interactive parts are choosing what to do and the simplistic game (click on the quadrant of a circle that is in every shape) that you play in order to ‘develop’ your indie game.

You can choose to develop your game or other activities like listening to music, play with your cat or go for a walk.  The videos are on the whole fairly well done with good framing and lighting.  The best videos are the Creative Commons licensed ones that play whilst you are developing the game.  The music consists of many Russian bands/acts that you wouldn’t have heard of unless you are a native.  The game has a quirky sense of humour which tends to fall flat.  Fortunately, all the videos can be skipped, which is a good metaphor for the game.

You will unlock almost all of the achievements on your first time playing - all of them if you get the good ending.  Within half-an-hour you will have seen everything the game has to offer, and there is really no point in playing it again, unless you want the trading cards.  In the information about the game in the Steam store, the developer/publisher asks you to “Don't take this game too seriously!”  I was sent a key for the game; if you want to pay for it, bear in mind that there is not much game here, seriously.

reviewText:
So instead of a Visual Novel in the traditional sense, this is a visual novel in the very visual sense.... only almost no reading.

It features sequences of movies clipped together to simulate a week in the life of an indie developer. There were a few movies or text between movies that actually made me laugh, as the game even pokes fun at itself.

Some of the movies in the beginning seem to try to stress the feelings you might have being an indie developer, but toward the end they just get very abstract and I think the dev on this game, just went for random strange stuff that people would interpret in strange ways.

Music probably could have been more interesting, but most of it was in Russian(?), and so I couldn't really understand it.

Controls only exist really in the mini-game which consists of you spam clicking.... Really kinda boring and one dimensional.

Visuals - I would have to say interesting, though when you're wondering if something you've seen is the same thing or if it's something different, you tend to start realizing how bored you are because you want to analyze the waking up bit.
WARNING: while the game says that smoking is bad and features scenes of people smoking, what it fails to mention is that it could possibly cause someone an epileptic fit. While you have the ability to skip most movies, which would be fine if you realized in time, this particular video sequence occurs when you are supposed to be 'developing' the game (read as playing mini-game to beat the game).

Was extremely short, achievements are easy to get... But still not completely what I'd call a game.

Overall 4/10 - Just skip it :/

Every time I get a game free from a giveaway, I would try my best to play through it, see all that it has to offer and if possible, complete it in earnest. Then I would take the time to write an honest review, because for good or ill every review extends the exposure of the title in question, which is what most developers would prefer giveaway winners to help out on.

This title however, takes the absolute cake since it was just a bunch of movie clips mashed together under the pretence of a “game”. I fail to see any meaningful messages as I sat through the duration, I failed to see how this managed to get on Steam, I failed to see how moving pictures of a cat can be seen as any point of relevance to game development.

I am glad this title does not represent the indie field at large, and that games aren’t meant to be churned out in a week’s game, as this abomination suggested. Seriously, this is the first time where I genuinely felt like I’ve wasted my life on a giveaway.

reviewText:
TL;DR: A game making the point that you cannot make a game unless you devote a big chunk of your time to actually do it.

There, I spoiled it for you. But then again, Make it indie! has very few actual gameplay features. It advertises that it's a game about surviving as an indie developer for a week. The problem is, it's not really a game about that. It's hardly a game at all.

The concept sounds awesome. What do you have to do to make it through the week as an indie developer, to push for that deadline? Maybe you'd have to make a timetable and try to manage your time between game development, designing, art work, writing, sound design and also free time and relaxing. Require the player to put that into the right order to come up with the game. Perhaps even require keeping your hunger, exhaustion and focus at bay. Throw in a couple of events you need to take into account, like a birthday party or some special holiday. Voilà! So how's the execution of that anticipation in this game?

It's poor. It's outright appalling. It's the bare bones of what I expected with fluff all over it. In the game, every day you have a choice of basically two options: either use the time for developing the game or goofing around.

There are eight kinds of goofing around. Choosing any shows you a video of the developer goofing around: e.g. playing with his cat, being at a party or playing poker with his friends, with no gameplay whatsoever. Then the night comes and you get to see videos of weird dreams. They are potentially epilepsy inducing with all the flashing lights. All in all, no games were developed that day.

I found these videos to be artsy"

reviewText:
‘Make it indie!’ isn’t meant to be a game. It is one of those completely out-of-this-world college art films which try to be so non-mainstream that nobody understands them. And it somehow ended up as a Steam store item.

In our case this product is a collection of about a dozen of 1-2 minute collage videos that represent the everyday life of a Russian indie game developer who struggles between his self-imposed obligations of creating a game or just living life as it is.

If one really wants to analyse it as an allegory, maybe interesting discussions could come out of it. Although I highly doubt that this was the intention of the developer. It seems to be intentionally bad as a game because this was his actual point with it.

This isn't really a game. If it was, it would be really bad, but it feels like I can't even call it bad because its not really a game.

It's basically one week as a hipster indie game developer. You can choose to develop the game, which you have one week to make (with no obvious reason to have it done - you don't have a boss and you don't work for a company) or you can do something a real person might want to do, but in reality is very boring for anybody not involved (that's you). If you choose the latter, you are shown a video of somebody doing the thing you picked. Of course, doing one thing, like playng with your friends or 'watching the rain', takes up a whole day. If you choose to develop, you are given a very easy, very boring, very repitive and very unsimilar-to-making0a-real-game mini game where there are a bunch of circles made from tiles and you have to pick which tile is in every circle. It's really boring.

When your day is finished, you are shown crossing out the day on a Russian calendar followed by a dream video. Or something, I skipped it.

If you waste your time doing non-game developing things, you get an achievement for not finishing the game and if you develop the game, you get an achievement for finishing the game.

I got this for €0.50 from a coupon, and I made over €0.30 back from selling the trading cards. Trust me, it is not even worth the €0.20 I paid. Just don't waste your time.

reviewText:
I am not as dead against this as many people are but it is not something that I can recomend to anyone.

It is clearly intended as more of an interactive movie than a fully fledged game so bear that in mind if considering  a purchase.

Make it Indie is a russian game designed as a jibe at the process of indie game development and can easily be seen as a take-down of the current indie game market. It contains a lot of poorly translated english but that's not surprising considering A) It's an indie game B) it's a Russian game, they were clearly not going to have enough money to get a decent translation performed.

Gameplay there is very little to talk about as it consists of a manu that links to several different video clips and a singluar mini-game where you click on one of four segments of a circle. It's very basic but the 'gameplay' section is clearly intended to reflect the monotony of developing a game, this does not make it good or enjoayble however.

Clearly effort has gone into this game, however it's also clear that it could have been made in a 24 hour game competition without loosing much.

As for the fact is was developed using Unity Personal, so what? Unity Personal does not mean that it should not be sold. Games devloped in Unity Personal can still be sold commercially as it says in the license when you download it.

CONCLUSION - 6/10

Although I cannot actually recomend this game it is not at all bad for 79p (I assume prices will vary outside the UK) It is very basic but what do you expect for what it is. There is no gameplay but you might extract some pleasure through playing through it once, and if you want some quick cards/achievements then you cannot go wrong.

reviewText:
It's games like this on Steam that make me feel as if there should be a mixed option.
This game had an interesting concept... but fell flat. The game is VERY short and if you keep
on pressing '0', you can beat it in under 10 minutes. The achievments are VERY easy to get, and saying that you got all the achievments for this game should not be impressive.
The game is surprisingly cheap, and it justifies it's price quite well... even though I bought it for 80 cents yesterday compared to the 99 cents it actually costs.
I would also like to say that visuals are quite nice, and though I don't like FMV games, the real-life footage is REALLY good.
However, the gameplay is  VERY  weak. You would think the main course of the game is developing games, but developing games is more like a puzzle your school gives when you have nothing better to do; it's engaging, but after you put some pieces together, you just don't want to finish it.

VERDICT (for those who are too lazy to read what I've wrote):
Make it indie is surprisingly cheap, has great visuals, and an engaging idea.
However, to justify the 99 cents and the (what feels like) VERY short development time,
the gameplay is sadly dull and you can beat it in under 5 minutes...
which would explain my extremelly short play time.
(also the fact that this was released on April Fools Day should make anyone buying this feel violated)
4/10
